body: THREE years ago, Alan Marks, a Park Slope real-estate agent, would watch a one-bedroom apartment on Sackett Street, in an area known as the Lower Slope, languish on his list of rentals for longer than a month. Prospective tenants would take one look at the block, dotted with abandoned buildings and a few scraggly trees, turn up their noses and keep
title: The Boom in Park Slope

body: Suggesting that the case had not been worth prosecuting, a judge in Brooklyn refused yesterday to impose a penalty on a former school principal convicted of diverting $2,200 in school money to set up a weight-lifting and exercise room at his school for himself and his teachers. ''The District Attorney could have spent his resources and time
title: Judge Declines to Penalize Principal for an Illicit Gym

body: Along Fifth Avenue, what was once a strip of empty storefronts, bodegas and Chinese restaurants with bulletproof windows is changing into one of Brooklyn's most eclectic commercial thoroughfares. Several cafes, a new herb store offering root tonics and a number of antique stores have sprouted along Fifth Avenue, the main artery of the ''other''
title: A Funky Renewal Transforms Fifth Avenue

body: There are no brownstones in Bangladesh. But in the brownstone corridors of Brooklyn, the men who wipe grime off the aging stone buildings, restore their cracking stoops and spruce up their cornices are increasingly immigrants from Bangladesh. Sometimes, people ask, 'Where did you learn to do this?' " said Mostafizur Rahman, a construction worker
title: Building Lives on Brooklyn's Scaffolds

body: IT is April 12 and I am standing in the ring of the old Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden. I can feel the weight of 4,500 pairs of eyes all bearing down on me from the sloping stands that seem to ascend endlessly into a dark infinity. The lights overhead are unnaturally hot. The first-round bell rings and for the first time, I am forced to look
title: Was It My Night?

body: It was a night for the insiders and a night that politicians who normally do not agree on much came together to anoint a candidate. And it was the night after a night on which Democratic loyalists pounded on doors in this sprawling Brooklyn district, lining up proxy votes from those who would be unable to attend the meeting at which Seymour Lachman
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Ever the Loyal Democrat, Lachman Reaps His Reward
